page.title: 11Longage Farm; lambing
page.content: Lambing starts at the beginning of March and the lambing average this year was 170%. The lambs are taken to Canterbury Market where they are sold. They usually weigh 16 kilograms. Sheep are dipped twice a year in autumn and in summer to prevent scab, tics and lice. The sheep are dipped on the premises and must stay under water in the dip for one minute. At the beginning of June the sheep shearing starts. Contract shearers shear the sheep and Kent lambs. There is still a demand for lambs' wool. The shearing takes one day. Each fleece weighs about nine pounds. The sheep have their feet trimmed twice a year because of foot rot. Mr Ridley-Day does all the work on his farm with the help of a shepherd and a sheepdog.
